evidence_span: Oxidation rates of Zircaloy-4 cladding tubes have been measured in hydrogen-steam mixtures at 1200 to 1700°C

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_055_chunk1
evidence_span: oxide layer thicknesses have been measured as a function of time, steam supply rate, and hydrogen overpressure

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_055_chunk1
evidence_span: The oxidation rates in the mixtures were compared with similar data obtained in pure steam and helium-steam environments under otherwise identical conditions

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_055_chunk1
evidence_span: The oxidation rates in the mixtures were compared with similar data obtained in pure steam and helium-steam environments under otherwise identical conditions

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_055_chunk1
evidence_span: The rates in pure steam and helium-steam mixtures were equivalent and comparable to the parabolic rates obtained under steam-saturated conditions

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_055_chunk1
evidence_span: The rates in pure steam and helium-steam mixtures were equivalent and comparable to the parabolic rates obtained under steam-saturated conditions

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_055_chunk1
evidence_span: when the helium was replaced with hydrogen of equivalent partial pressure, a significantly smaller oxidation rate was observed

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_055_chunk1
evidence_span: For high steam supply rates, the oxidation kinetics in a hydrogen-steam mixture were parabolic, but the rate was smaller than for pure steam or helium-steam mixtures

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_055_chunk1
evidence_span: The ratio of the parabolic rate for hydrogen-steam to that for pure steam decreased with increasing temperature and decreasing steam supply rate

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_055_chunk1
evidence_span: For smaller steam supply rates, significantly smaller linear oxidation rates were observed in the hydrogen-steam mixture

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_055_chunk1
evidence_span: Weight gain, corrected for hydrogen uptake, in the hydrogen-steam mixture was approximately half of that measured in pure steam

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_055_chunk1

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_055_chunk1
evidence_span: Increased weight gain and accelerated oxidation due to breakaway-type porous oxide formation have been reported for volume ratios ranging from 0.3 to 0.5 at 1000 to 1100°C

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_055_chunk1
evidence_span: For volume ratios ≳0.6, weight gain was significantly smaller in the hydrogen-steam mixture than in pure steam for the same temperature range

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_055_chunk1
evidence_span: Cathcart et al reported no significant effect of 5 mol% hydrogen, mixed with steam, on the oxidation kinetics of Zircaloy-4 at 1100 to 1300°C

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_055_chunk1
evidence_span: we have conducted a series of oxidation experiments in pure steam, hydrogen-steam, and helium-steam mixtures under a wider range of conditions, especially under conditions that are believed to be more important for understanding the fuel-rod behavior in a degraded-core accident, that is, higher cladding temperatures (>1200°C) and higher hydrogen fractions (>0.5)

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_055_chunk5
evidence_span: Specimens oxidized either in pure steam or in heliumsteam mixtures showed hydrogen contents of 100 to 350 weight ppm.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_055_chunk5
evidence_span: Specimens oxidized in hydrogen-steam mixtures contained higher hydrogen concentrations of 600 to 2000 weight ppm.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_055_chunk5
evidence_span: We have noticed an unusual pinkish oxide color, similar to that of clay, for all the specimens tested at 1705°C and in a mixture of hydrogen and steam with steam supply rates ≲0.3 g/min (Fig. 6).

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_055_chunk5
evidence_span: For specimens with comparable oxide-layer thickness but oxidized in pure steam or helium-steam mixtures, the oxide color was invariably dark gray.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_055_chunk5
evidence_span: The oxide formed in pure steam contained less than 0.03 weight % hydrogen and corresponds to a composition close to ZrO₂.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_055_chunk5
evidence_span: The composition of the oxide skin observed for the smallest steam supply rate in Fig. 10 corresponds to ZᵣO₀.₉₉₆H₀.₉₆₅, which is close to ZrOH.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_055_chunk5
evidence_span: Figure 10 shows the results obtained from several specimens oxidized at 1705°C for ~120 s in various hydrogen-steam mixtures.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_055_chunk5
evidence_span: McClaine and Coppel [12] in their investigation of the electrical conductivity of tetragonal ZrO₂ at 1100 to 1550°C have reported increased electronic conductivity (hence, decreased ionic conductivity) in hydrogen-steam mixtures compared with similar measurements in carbon monoxide-carbon dioxide mixtures.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_055_chunk5
evidence_span: McClaine and Coppel [12] in their investigation of the electrical conductivity of tetragonal ZrO₂ at 1100 to 1550°C have reported increased electronic conductivity (hence, decreased ionic conductivity) in hydrogen-steam mixtures compared with similar measurements in carbon monoxide-carbon dioxide mixtures.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_055_chunk6
evidence_span: Oxidation rates for Zircaloy-4 tubes at 1216 to 1705°C are slower in hydrogen-steam mixtures than in pure steam or helium-steam environments

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_055_chunk6
evidence_span: Oxidation in hydrogen-steam mixtures is parabolic or linear depending on the Zircaloy temperature, pressures of steam and hydrogen at the gas/oxide boundary, and oxide layer thickness

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_055_chunk6
evidence_span: The linear oxidation rates are smaller than the parabolic rates

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_055_chunk6
evidence_span: The parabolic oxidation rate in a hydrogen-steam mixture, which is smaller than the corresponding rate in steam, decreases with decreasing partial pressure of oxygen at the gas/oxide interface or increasing hydrogen-to-steam ratio

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_055_chunk6
evidence_span: At temperatures ≳1500°C, the retardation of the parabolic oxidation rate relative to pure steam for a given gas flow and hydrogen-steam composition is more pronounced at higher temperatures

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_055_chunk6
evidence_span: Laboratory experiments were performed in the temperature range 1800 to 2000°C in inert gas to study the chemical interaction between solid uranium dioxide (UO2) and liquid Zircaloy-4

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_055_chunk6
evidence_span: the wettability of UO2 by molten Zircaloy as functions of time and Zircaloy oxygen concentration

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_055_chunk6
evidence_span: The wettability, however, depends strongly on the oxygen content of the Zircaloy and therefore on the time of UO2/Zircaloy contact. The wettability improves with increasing oxygen content

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_055_chunk6
evidence_span: Zircaloy reduces UO2 to form a homogeneous [uranium, zirconium, oxygen (U,Zr,O)] melt at low oxygen concentrations or a heterogeneous (U,Zr,O) melt which contains (U,Zr)O2 particles at high oxygen concentrations

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_055_chunk6
evidence_span: During cooling, the (U,Zr,O) melt decomposes into a (U,Zr) alloy with high uranium content and oxygen-stabilized α-Zr(O)

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_055_chunk6
evidence_span: The amount of fuel which can be liquefied by molten cladding depends on the initial oxygen content of the melt. Oxygen-free liquid Zircaloy can dissolve considerably more UO2 than Zircaloy rich in oxygen
